column1: An unpleasant inside is what a venerable elder should have; a venerable elder should not have an unpleasant mien.
column2: Inú burúkú làgbà ń ní, àgbà kì í ní ojú burúkú.

column1: The wound left by a cutlass may heal, but the wound left by speech does not heal.
column2: Ipa ọgbẹ́ ní ń sàn; ipa ohùn kì í sàn.

column1: One sees only other peoples' occiputs; only others can see one's own.
column2: Ìpàkọ́ onípàkọ́ là ń rí; eniẹlẹ́ni ní ń rí tẹni.

column1: The eyelashes do not make dew; a venerable old beard does not behave like an ingenue.
column2: Ìpéǹpéjú ò ní enini; àgbàlagbà irùngbọ̀n ò ṣe òlòó.

column1: There is no cheating in photography; it is just as you sit that you will find your image.
column2: Ìrẹ́jẹ ò sí nínúu fọ́tò; bí o bá ṣe jókòó ni o ó bá araà rẹ.

column1: The likeness of a particular type of cloth is not lacking among those in fashion.
column2: Irú aṣọ ò tán nínu àṣà.

column1: The likeness of an elephant is not scarce in Alọ.
column2: Irú erin ò tán ní Àlọ́.

column1: The horse-tail whisk does not shun Ifá; high-fashion maiden, pause awhile and give me a greeting.
column2: Ìrùkẹ̀rẹ̀ kì í yan Ifá lódì; oge, dúró o kí mi.

column1: The fugitive does not stop to pull a thorn “from his/her feet”; the fugitive does not stop to clear dinner dishes.
column2: Ìsáǹsá ò yọ ẹ̀gún; ìsáǹsá kì í káwo ọbẹ̀.

column1: Destitution does not attach to one at a particular place; suffering does not attack a person at a particular place; if one walks like a wretch into a town, if one looks like a loser when one enters a town, it is with a miserable calabash that the people will offer one water to drink.
column2: Ìṣẹ̀ ò ti ibìkan mú ẹni; ìyà ò tibìkan jẹ èèyàn; bí o bá rìnrìn òṣì, bí o bá ojú ìṣẹ́ wọ̀lú, igbákúgbá ni wọn ó fi bu omi fún ẹ mu.

column1: A vine as thick as a palm-tree trunk will not stop an elephant; whatever vine attempts to stop an elephant from going to Alọ will go with the elephant instead.
column2: Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ń lọ.

column1: Character is always remarkable (or good) in the opinion of its owner.
column2: Ìwà ní ń jọ oníwà lójú.

column1: A pawned person always dances with a pawned person.
column2: Ìwọ̀fà ní ń mú ìwọ̀fà jó.

column1: The measure of the rat is the measure of the nest; a robin does not live on a cushion.
column2: Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù.

column1: Trading insults brings ruin to an elder's home.
column2: Ìwọ̀sí ní í ba ilé àgbà jẹ́.

column1: The wife who whips a relative of her husband is asking for stern rebuke.
column2: Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́.

column1: Sedately is the way an elderly masquerader dances.
column2: Jẹ́jẹ́ leégún àgbà ń jó.

column1: The jòkùmọ̀ plant looks like the indigo plant; it is the indigo dye, though, we have use for.
column2: Jòkùmọ̀ọ́ ṣe bí ẹ̀lú, aró la bẹ̀ lọ́wẹ̀.

column1: To see a person in the streets is not the same as going home with the person.
column2: Ká ríni lóde ò dàbíi ká báni délé.

column1: Having people to advise one is nothing like knowing how to take advice.
column2: Ká ríni sọ̀rọ̀ fúnni ò dàbíi ká sọ̀rọ̀ fúnni ká gbà.

column1: If one is spoken to one should listen; if one is advised one should heed the advice; one should seek direction from straggling wayfarers in order than one's life might be pleasant.
column2: Ká wí fún ẹni ká gbọ́; ká sọ̀rọ̀ fúnni ká gbà; kà bèrè ọnà lọ́wọ́ èrò tó kù lẹ́yìn kàyè baà lè yẹni.

column1: If one is spoken to one should listen; if one is advised one should accept the advice; refusal to listen to speech and refusal to accept advice leads to using the calabash of deprivation as a drinking cup.
column2: Ká wí fúnni ká gbọ́; ká sọ̀rọ̀ fúnni ká gbà; à-wí-ìgbọ́, à-gbọ́-ìgbà ní ń fi igbá àdánù bu omi mu.

column1: To heed advice is what best becomes a human being.
column2: Ká wí ká gbà ló yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.

column1: Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, “I do not like it, and I will not accept it” is how the imbecile ends the discussion.
column2: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “N ò fẹ́, n ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ń pẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.

column1: Rather than prostrate oneself in homage or obeisance to a Hausa person, one should rather die.
column2: Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú.

column1: Rather than cry out, the ram will die.
column2: Kàkà kí àgbò ké, àgbò a kú.

column1: Rather than the father carrying the son's cutlass home from the farm, each will carry his own.
column2: Kàkà kí bàbá ran ọmọ ní àdá bọ oko, oníkálukú a gbé tiẹ̀.

column1: Rather than bend backwards, the crab's claws will break.
column2: Kàkà kí iga akàn ó padà sẹyìn, a kán.

column1: Rather than the lion serving as carrier for the leopard, each will hunt separately.
column2: Kàkà kí kìnìún ṣe akápò ẹkùn, ọlọ́dẹ a mú ọdẹ ẹ̀ ṣe.

column1: The toad is only slightly taller than the earth.
column2: Kékeré lọ̀pọ̀lọ́ fi ga ju ilẹ̀ lọ.

column1: Let the slave know him/herself as a slave; let the pawn know him/herself as a pawn; let the well born person know him/herself as the child of God.
column2: Kí ẹrú mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú; kí ìwọ̀fà mọ ara ẹ̀ níwọ̀fà; kí ọmọlúwàbí mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú Ọlọ́run ọba.

column1: Responsibility does not devolve on the father only for him to say it is his son's duty.
column2: Kì í dọwọ́ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ.

column1: What is the point of bragging on account of an ass which when one rides on it one's feet drag on the ground?
column2: Kí ni àǹfàní kẹ̀tẹ̀kẹ̀tẹ̀ lára kẹ́tẹ́kẹ́tẹ́ à-gùn-fẹsẹ̀-wọ́lẹ̀?

column1: What does a bald man want in the stall of the barber?
column2: Kí ni apárí ń wá ní ìsọ̀ onígbàjámọ̀?

column1: What did Dáàró own before he claimed he was robbed?
column2: Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olèé kó òun?

column1: What is it that the seller of gbégbé leaves has to sell that she complains that the market is slow?
column2: Kí ni eléwée gbégbé ń tà tí ó ń sọ pé ọjà ò tà?

column1: What would take the vulture to the stall of the hair dresser?
column2: Kí ni ìbá mú igún dé ọ̀dọ̀ọ onídìrí?

column1: What has the bachelor to feel superior about, such that while he is roasting yams he is whistling the song, “What one does fills them with jealousy”?
column2: Kí ni ó yá àpọ́n lórí tó fiṣu síná tó ń súfèé pé “bí a ti ń ṣe ni inú ń bí wọn”?

column1: What is the calabash owner doing that the china plate owner cannot do?
column2: Kí ni onígbá ń ṣe tí aláwo ò lè ṣe?

column1: What can the head do that the shoulder cannot do? The shoulder carried a load and earned three hundred cowries; the head sold its own for two hundred and twenty cowries.
column2: Kí ni orí ń ṣe tí èjìká ò lè ṣe? Èjìká ru ẹrù ó gba ọ̀ọ́dúnrún; orí ta tiẹ̀ ní ogúnlúgba.

column1: What use do the people of Ilorin have for Ahmadu? Even goats are so named.
column2: Kí ni wọ́n ti ń ṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ń jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

column1: Durable hand-woven cloth is the material for shiftless people; loom-woven cloth is the material for the elders; whichever elder cannot afford loom-woven cloth should strive for durable hand-woven cloth.
column2: Kíjìpá laṣọ ọ̀lẹ; òfì laṣọ àgbà; àgbà tí ò ní tòfì a rọ́jú ra kíjìpá.

column1: He does not buy, he has no money, yet he sits sulkily before the seller of bean fritters.
column2: Kò rà, kò lówó lọ́wọ́, ó ń wú tutu níwájú onítumpulu.

column1: There is no one pleased “by one's success” except one's head.
column2: Kò sí ẹni tó dùn mọ́ àfi orí ẹni.

column1: Without-me-in-an-assembly-the-assembly-is-not-complete deceives only himself/herself.
column2: Kò sí mi lájọ àjọ ò kún: ara ẹ̀ ló tàn jẹ.

column1: There is nothing Ṣango can do to enable itself to rage in a drought.
column2: Kò sí ohun tí Ṣàngó lè ṣe kó jà lẹ́ẹ̀rùn.

column1: He-was-not-at-home never fails to prove his valor with his mouth.
column2: Kò-sí-nílé kì í jagun ẹnu tì.

column1: Swiftly-consumed-swiftly-consumed is the way a dog laps up water.
column2: Kó-tán-kó-tán lajá ń lá omi.

column1: The butterfly likens itself to a bird, but it cannot do what a bird can do.
column2: Labalábá fi ara ẹ̀ wẹ́yẹ, kò lè ṣe ìṣe ẹyẹ.

column1: Ash mixed with water likens itself to indigo dye, but it cannot do what the dye can do; the large red bean likens itself to corn.
column2: Lábúlábú  fara wé aró, kò lè ṣe bí aró; pòpòǹdó  fara wé àgbàdo.

column1: Were So-and-So alive he would transform himself into a brown monkey; did the person who preceded him ever transform himself into any kind of monkey?
column2: Lágbájá ìbá wà a di ìjímèrè; ẹni tó bá níwájú di oloyo?

column1: A limp is no great asset for a person wishing to stop a fight; a masquerader's child is no easy playmate.
column2: Láká-ǹ-láká ò ṣéé fi làjà; ọmọ eégún ò ṣéé gbé ṣeré.

column1: One does not wear ẹtù  cap as a matter of course; only certain people have heads suited for such a cap.
column2: Lásán kọ́ là ń dé ẹtù; ó ní ẹni tórí ẹ̀ ń bá ẹtù mu.

column1: Cattle egrets never lay black eggs; only white eggs do they lay.
column2: Lékèélékèé ò yé ẹyin dúdú; funfun ni wọ́n ńy é ẹyin wọn.

column1: Save face with members of your household and save face with complete strangers, such a person loses face with himself/herself.
column2: Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ń tẹ́.

column1: A cow may not boast in the presence of a horse.
column2: Màlúù ò lè lérí níwájú ẹṣin.

column1: Lightning is no good for roasting yams.
column2: Mànàmáná ò ṣéé sun iṣu.

column1: “Were I at Ọ̀yọ́ I would own a horse by now”: he should have numerous sheep to his name in this town.
column2: “M̀bá wà lỌ́yọ̀ọ́ mà ti so ẹṣin”; àgùntàn-an rẹ̀ á níye nílẹ̀yí.

column1: How large a community is Ejigbo that one of its settlements is named Ayegbogbo “The whole world”?
column2: Mélòó lÈjìgbò tí ọ̀kan ẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Ayé-gbogbo?

column1: I have become old and wise, but childish play has not ceased to appeal to me.
column2: Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi.

column1: Having grown old I miss youthfulness.
column2: Mo dàgbà tán èweé wù mí.

column1: “I am beautiful, I am beautiful!” has ugliness as its conclusion.
column2: “Mo dára, mo dára,” àìdára ní ń pẹ̀kun ẹ̀.

column1: “I am all-wise, I am all-knowing” kept the wasp from having as much venom as the bee.
column2: “Mo gbọ́n tán, mo mọ̀ràn tán” kì í jẹ́ kí agbọ́n lóró bí oyin.

column1: and also “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ gún,” . . .
column2: Compare “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ gùn” . . .

column1: “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tan,”. . .
column2: Compare “Mo gbọ́n tán, . . . ”

column1: also “Mo gbọ́n tan, . . . ”
column2: Compare the preceding entry,

column1: and “Mo mỌ̀bàrà...”
column2: Compare “Mo gbọ́n tán, . . . ”

column1: “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ gùn, . . .”
column2: Compare “Mo gbọ́n tan, . . . ”

column1: “I am full” means “I am full”; “I decline” means “I decline”; eating with abandon, that is the father of all greediness.
column2: “Mo yó” ń jẹ́ “mo yó,” “mo kọ̀” ń jẹ́ “mo kọ̀”; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni.

column1: “I will get my money's worth out of these trousers”; the grown man only winds up exposing his bare buttocks to the world.
column2: “N óò gba owóò mi lára ṣòkòtò yìí”; ìdí làgbàlagbà ń ṣí sílẹ̀.

column1: The humpback's child has presented a formidable dilemma: he cries, “Mother, mother, carry me on your back!”
column2: Nláńlá lọmọ abuké ń dá: ó ní “Ìyá, ìyá, òun ó pọ̀n.”

column1: Where did you discard all other names and picked for yourself the name Làm̀bòròkí?
column2: Níbo lo forúkọ sí tí ò ń jẹ́ Làm̀bòròkí?

column1: When we were stacking the corn we did not stack some for the brown rat.
column2: Nígbà tí à ń to ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si.

column1: Since you claim to be a seasoned rider, how come your horse has gone lame?
column2: Nígbà tí o mọ̀ ọ́ gùn, ẹṣin ẹ ẹ́ ṣe ṣẹ́ orókún?

column1: Since when did a tiger-hide sac become a thing a child uses to harvest okro?
column2: Nígbà wo làpò ẹkùn-ún di ìkálá fọ́mọdé?

column1: Salt loses its good quality and becomes like saltpeter.
column2: Ó bọ́ lọ́wọ́ iyọ̀ ó dòbu.

column1: The moon loses its esteem and shines all night long.
column2: Ó bọ́ lọ́wọ́ oṣù ó dàràn-mọ́jú.

column1: Your eyes flinch not and your mouth is unstoppable, but you do not know nine times nine.
column2: O dájú dánu, o ò mọ ẹ̀sán mẹ́sàn-án.

column1: Not until the gathering of trousers will Ládugbo know itself as a miscreant.
column2: Ó di àwùjọ ṣòkòtò kí ládugbó tó mọ ara rẹ̀ Lábèṣè.

column1: It will not be until the end of days before the humpback realizes that a hump is not a child.
column2: Ó di ọjọ́ alẹ́ kábuké tó mọ̀ pé iké kì í ṣọmọ.

column1: You do not know what black eyed peas are like for dinner.
column2: O kò mọ ẹ̀wà lóńjẹ à-jẹ-sùn.

column1: You are reduced to eating last year's antelope in your stew, and yet you claim to have attained the height of good fortune.
column2: Ò ń jàgbọ̀nrín èṣín lọ́bẹ̀, o ní o ti tó tán.

column1: Because you are carrying a huge pot you strut; what would one say to the person carrying the divinity Yemoja?
column2: O ru ládugbó ò ń rerá; kí ni ká sọ fẹ́ni tó ru Òrìṣàa Yemọja?

column1: It might be seemly for a masquerader to chase one off a corn farm, but it is not seemly for Pákọ̀kọ̀ to chase one in the middle of town.
column2: Ó tọ́ kí eégún léni lóko àgbàdo, èwo ni ti Pákọ̀kọ̀ láàrin ìlú?

column1: Everybody has a right to say the yams are not well cooked, but not the bàtá drummer.
column2: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó sọ pé iṣu ò jiná, kò yẹ alubàtá.

column1: It is fitting for everybody to bargain to reduce the cost of dyeing clothes, but not the bed wetter.
column2: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé.

column1: Everyone can justifiably say, “God, who has left nothing undone,” but not a eunuch.
column2: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó sọ pé “Ọlọ́run a-ṣèkan-má-kù,” kò yẹ akúkó.

column1: It is only in a small stream that the crab can make its oil; when it becomes huge and swift the river sweeps the crab away.
column2: Odò kékeré lalákàn-án ti lè fọ́ epo; bó bá di àgàdàm̀gbá tán, odò a gbé alákàn lọ.

column1: The law will assert itself, “as in the case of” a junior wife flogging the child of the senior wife.
column2: Òfin ni yó sọ ara ẹ̀; ìyàwó tí ń na ọmọ ìyáálé.

column1: The war that the two-eyed person saw and fled is the same the one-eyed person vows he will join.
column2: Ogun tí olójú méjì rí sá ni olójú kan ní òún ń lọ jà.

column1: Only two things are proper for a warrior: the warrior goes to war and drives the enemy off; the warrior goes to war and dies in battle.
column2: Ohun méjì ló yẹ Ẹ̀ṣọ́: Ẹ̀ṣọ́ jà, ó lé ogun; Ẹ̀ṣọ́ jà ó kú sógun.

column1: What one sells is what one eats; that does not apply to the kerosene seller.
column2: Ohun tí à ń tà là ń jẹ; kì í ṣe ọ̀rọ̀ oní-kẹrosíìnì.

column1: Whatever the ant is able to carry is what it says is its full measure.
column2: Ohun tí eèrá bá lè gbé ní ń pè ní ìgànnìkó.

column1: That which the cricket attempted and broke a thigh, the aláàńtètè asks to be permitted to attempt.
column2: Ohun tí ìrẹ̀ẹ́ ṣe tó fi kán lápá, aláàńtèté ní kí wọ́n jẹ́ kí òun ó ṣe è.

column1: A thing that is not worth the least amount of money should not prove a hardship for an elder.
column2: Ohun tí kò tó okòó kì í jẹ àgbà níyà.

column1: What the imbecile does to himself is far worse than what he does to others.
column2: Ohun tí wèré fi ń s̩e ara ẹ̀, ó pọ̀ ju ohun tó fi ń ṣẹ ọmọ ẹlòmíràn lọ.

column1: One boasts only about things proper to boast about; whoever heard of the boast, “By this time yesterday I had given my parent-in-law the beating of his life.”?
column2: Ohun tó ṣeé faga là ń faga sí; èwo ni,“Ìwòyí àná mo ti na ànaà mi fága-fàga”?

column1: It is in a visitor's presence that one gets into debt; it is in her absence that one repays the debt.
column2: Ojú àlejò la ti ń jẹ gbèsè; ẹ̀yìn-in ẹ̀ là ń san án.

column1: The eye, father of the body; nothing is as valuable as the eye; nothing is as difficult to achieve as the status of elder.
column2: Ojú baba ara; awọ́n bí ojú; aṣòró dà bí àgbà.

column1: It is not in the presence of the flame that water-yam grows hair.
column2: Ojú iná kọ́ lewùrà ń hurun.

column1: The colobus monkey is never so reduced in circumstances that it becomes a land-hugging creature; the vulture is never so badly off that it becomes the equal of a chicken.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́n ẹdun kó dẹni ilẹ̀; ìṣẹ́ kì í ṣẹ́ igún kó di ojúgbà adìẹ.

column1: A head of a household is never so hard up that he sweeps his compound with his bare hands.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́n baálé ilé kó fọwọ́ gbálẹ̀ ilé ẹ̀.

column1: An Ifá diviner-priest is never so hard up that he asks for yesterday's sacrifice.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́n babaláwo kó bèèrè ẹbọ àná.

column1: A dead person cannot be so desperate as to appeal to a living person for deliverance.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́n òkú ọ̀run kó ní kí ará ayé gba òun.

column1: One should not become so desperate that one takes one's younger sister as wife.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́nni ká fàbúrò ẹni ṣaya.

column1: One should never be so benighted that one covers oneself in rags.
column2: Ojú kì í pọnni ká fàkísà bora.

column1: One's circumstances do not so deteriorate that one becomes red in teeth.
column2: Ojú kì í pọ́nni ká pọ́n léyín.

column1: A person only newly acquainted with wealth; he has a son and names him Ọlaniyọnu.
column2: Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu.

column1: The medicine man lacks all shame, he announces that his parent-in-law is dying.
column2: Ojú ò ti oníṣègùn, ó ní àna òun ń kú lọ.

column1: Shame upon the wasp; the wasp has a nest but no honey.
column2: Ojú ti agbọ́ń agbọ́n láfà kò léro.

column1: The giant bush rat and its child become equals in their hole; the mother cracks palm-nuts with its teeth, and the child does the same thing.
column2: Òkété pẹ̀lú ọmọ ẹ̀ẹ́ di ọgbọọgba sínú ihò; nígba tí ìyá ń feyín pàkùrọ́, ọmọ náà ń feyín pa á pẹ̀lú.

column1: Darkness does not know who deserves deference; it consulted the oracle Ifá for “Who might you be?”
column2: Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún “Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn”?

column1: A person who has only one wife does not form a circle for a fight.
column2: Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja.

column1: A one-eyed person does not attempt standing somersaults.
column2: Olójúkan kì í tàkìtì òró.

column1: The omele drummer does not vow that there will be an earth-shaking performance on the morrow.
column2: Olómele kì í sọ pé igi yó dàá lóde lọ́la.

column1: The rich man eats slowly and at leisure; the poor person eats fast and with anxiety; the poor man who keeps company with a wealthy man is exceeding his station.
column2: Olówó jẹun jẹ́jẹ́; òtòṣì jẹun tìpà-tìjàn; òtòṣì tí ń bá ọlọ́rọ̀ rìn, akọ ojú ló ń yá.

column1: It is a rich person that keeps company with a wealthy person; only people of equal standing play together.
column2: Olówó ní ń bá ọlọ́rọ̀ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ń bá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré.

column1: It is a rich person that eats pounded yams worth two thousand cowries.
column2: Olówó ní ń jẹ iyán ẹgbàá.

column1: A minor chief should not act garrulously in the presence of a king.
column2: Olóyè kékeré kì í ṣe fáàárí níwájú ọba.

column1: Today, the antelope falls into the ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
column2: Òní, ẹtú jìnfìn, ọ̀la, ẹtú jìnfìn; ẹtu nìkan lẹran tó wà nígbó?

column1: The shameless person does not know what is fitting; the shameless person is off to raid a farm, and he takes his wife along; the husband steals staple yams, the wife steals wateryams.
column2: Oníbàjẹ́ ò mọra; oníbàjẹ́ ń lọ sóko olè ó mú obìnrin lọ; ọkọ́ kó akọṣu, ìyàwó kó ewùrà.

column1: The bàtá drummer does not enter a mosque and ask “Where is the Imam?”
column2: Oníbàtá kì í wọ mọ́ṣáláṣí kó ní “Lèmámù ńkọ́?”

column1: The excessively attentive visitor “who” extends hospitality greetings to the host.
column2: Onífunra àlejò tí ń tètè ṣe onílé pẹ̀lẹ́.

column1: The person with goitre offers a ridiculously low price for beads; were the beads seller to accept her offer she would have no neck to string the beads around.
column2: Onígẹ̀gẹ́ fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ dọ́pọ̀; onílẹ̀kẹ̀ ìbá gbowo, ko rọ́rùn fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ so.

column1: The host is eating the fruits of the gbìngbindo tree; the visitor asks to be treated to some black-eyed peas.
column2: Onílé ń jẹ èso gbìngbindò; alèjòó ní kí wọ́n ṣe òun lọ́wọ́ kan ẹ̀wà.

column1: The Ṣàngó worshipper who dances and does not shake his skirt: he does not disgrace Ṣàngó but himself.
column2: OníṢàngó tó jó tí kò gbọn yẹ̀rì: àbùkùu Ṣàngó kọ́; àbùkù ara ẹ̀ ni.
